caption: Looking for a quick meal tonight after a tough game of ultimate frisbee, I tossed together a variation of EatingWell’s Warm Quinoa Salad with Edamame & Tarragon. I cooked some shelled edamame with some pan toasted quinoa in vegetable broth and then tossed them with some diced roasted red peppers and a lemon vinaigrette. I lacked tarragon, so I made the dressing with a mix of thyme, marjoram and a dash of cayenne. Once plated I topped the salad with some toasted walnuts. Not bad for 30 minutes of work.

I had some red curry paste to use and Kelsey had been craving mussels lately, so I tossed EatingWell’s Thai Red Curry Mussels on this week’s menu and I’m AMAZED. After learning a lesson from my last attempt at red curry, I used whole coconut milk instead of the ‘lite’ and I doubled up on the curry paste. The grocery store didn’t have watercress, so I used a whole bunch of organic spinach instead but no worries, this dish as absurdly good. I even got a spoon out at the end to sop up the sauce. Best mussels eva…

I owe some co-workers big time after skipping out on an all night application rollout for a weekend of debauchery in New Orleans. Tomorrow morning they are getting my official apology - Good Eats Doughnuts. I made the dough as the recipe states, but I lacked pastry rings so I used a drinking glass and the cap of a tequila bottle to cut the doughnut rings. After frying in my dutch oven, I glazed half of them in Good Eats Doughnut Glaze and tossed the rest in powdered sugar. These wont last long in a cubicle environment.

After a long day of work, I wanted a little breakfast for dinner tonight. I followed most of EatingWell’s Kale & Potato Hash and was very satisfied with the result. To avoid the pre-cooked and shredded potatoes the recipe called for, I boiled and shredded red potatoes and left the skin on for a little more flavor/nutrition. I added an extra teaspoon of horseradish for a kick and to get a little more protein in this meal, I tossed a couple fried eggs on top. This recipe is definitely making it on the repeat list.

After an almost year long scallop hiatus, I decided to give them another shot tonight with EatingWell’s Toasted Quinoa Salad with Scallops & Snow Peas. I toasted and then cooked quinoa with some minced garlic, mixed in chopped snow peas and then tossed it in a soy sauce and sesame oil dressing with some diced red pepper and scallions. Once the salad was soaking, I pan seared some bay scallops that had been marinating in soy sauce before folding them in with the rest of the ingredients. These leftovers are going to make a bitchin’ lunch tomorrow.

I took Kelsey to Curry-Town tonight with EatingWell’s Cauliflower & Red Lentil Curry. I cooked up a sauce of curry powder, turmeric, red lentils, onion and water, then stirred in a mix of cauliflower florets, tomatoes and jalapenos. Once the cauliflower was softened, I folded in a hot mix of cumin seeds, garlic, ginger and cayenne. I finished the dish with some fresh squeezed lemon juice and chopped cilantro and then plated it on top of a bed of brown basmati rice and naan. This one hit the spot.

To meet this week’s cheese quota, I put EatingWell’s Broccoli-Cheese Pie on the menu. I coated my fav pie pan with panko bread crumbs and then poured in a mix of whole milk mozzarella cheese, eggs, cubed whole wheat bread, cooked onion, bacon, steamed broccoli florets, 1% milk and everybody’s favorite hot sauce: Frank’s Red Hot. Stupid excited for leftovers tomorrow.

I’ve been on a bit of an Indian kick lately, so I wanted to try making one of my favorites: Palak Paneer. To create the palak, I started with Allrecipes’ Absolutely Perfect Palak Paneer. I cooked a mix of onion, ginger, garlic, cumin, coriander, turmeric, a few dried red chili peppers and sour cream then slowly cooked in 3 and a half bunches of spinach. Once simmering, I blended the mix with a large quartered tomato and some fresh cilantro sprigs. After the palak was back in the pan and simmering, I pan fried some cubed paneer and tossed it in the mix. Not bad for a first attempt, but not quite up to Saffron’s standards.

After drooling over the episode last week, I decided to try out Good Eats’ Lamb Tikka Masala and I was not disappointed. I ground up a whole seed garam masala mix from TheSpiceHouse.com, then tossed cubed leg of lamb in the mix with a few other spices and some whole milk yogurt to marinade for about an hour. Once ready, I skewered the meat on some Flat Super Skewers and let them cook on the grill. Once charred, I tossed the meat in a blend of spices, onion, finger peppers, garlic, ginger and diced tomatoes then stirred in some light coconut milk. I garnished the dish with some chopped cilantro, added some long grain brown rice on the side and ended up licking my plate.

I decided to make Tuna Steak au Poivre tonight so I picked up a pair of Yellowfin tuna steaks on my way home from work. I roughly ground some whole black peppercorns in my mortel and pestle, then I put together the start of a pan sauce by mixing some soy sauce, ginger, garlic, mirin, white vinegar, brown sugar, honey, crushed red pepper and a dash of corn starch. Once my saute pan got nice and hot, I melted down a pad of butter and then seared the crap out of the pepper coated steaks for about 3-4 minutes per side. Once done, I tossed them in some foil pouches to finish and poured the sauce into the hot pan to cook. When it thickened, I drizzled the sauce over the steaks and a side salad.

Holy cannoli…my mouth is on FIRE! Needing a serious dose of veggies, I tried out EatingWell’s Tex-Mex Summer Squash Casserole. I baked a mix of diced yellow squash, Vidalia onion, green chiles, jalapenos and cheddar cheese. After 40 minutes or so, I spread some salsa and more cheese on top and baked it for another 30. When everything was nice and bubbly, I pulled out the dish and garnished the casserole with some sliced scallions and minced red onion. I’m going to need a bucket of water to get through leftovers tomorrow…

I love gruyere cheese and I’ve been all about homemade croutons lately so I decided try EatingWell’s Baked Cod Casserole. I cooked down some julienned onions in some white wine and then laid some pacific cod fillets spiced with salt, pepper and thyme on top. Once things cooked for a while, I added some spiced, cubed 12-grain bread that had been tossed in olive oil and some finely shredded gruyere cheese on top before throwing it all back in the oven. On the side was a quick cooked kale salad tossed with some balsamic vinegar, lemon juice, tahini, tomatoes and garlic.

I’ve been interested in trying out tempeh lately so I gave EatingWell’s Sesame-Honey Tempeh & Quinoa a shot. I cooked the tempeh in sesame oil and once it was browned, I tossed it in a soy sauce and honey mix with a little crushed red pepper to give it a kick. I then laid it on a bed of quinoa and a quick carrot slaw. I foresee this one will make its way back on the menu soon.

Short on time tonight, I threw together EatingWell’s Black Bean-Smothered Sweet Potatoes. Remembering the recipe was a tad bland last time, I almost doubled the cumin, added a good portion of hot chili powder and tossed in some chopped scallions. Fast, filling and delicious.

I’ve been in a curry craze lately, so I put EatingWell’s Tofu with Thai Curry Sauce on the menu this week. Following the recipe, I pan fried some crumbled tofu and cooked in a mix of spinach and red pepper, but I also added broccoli to help sop up the saucy goodness. Once the spinach wilted a tad, I stirred in a mix of red curry paste, coconut milk, brown sugar, cilantro and a few dashes of cayenne to give a kick.

For a lil more Good Eats this week, I tried out Good Eats’ Lentil Soup. I cooked a mier poix mix, green lentils, chicken broth, peeled tomatoes in basil, salt, pepper, freshly ground cumin and coriander in my dutch oven and then pureed it all with my stick blender (aka my fav kitchen toy). Since I didn’t have any grains of paradise, I doubled the ground cumin and black peppercorn. To add a tad of creaminess, I tossed in a dollop of sour cream before serving. I also added a quick grilled cheese with tomato on the side some good dippins’.

I needed some Good Eats in my life this week so I put of couple recipes on the menu. Tonight’s dish was Good Eats’ Wild Mushroom and Asparagus Risotto. I followed Mr Alton Brown's instructions to slowly cook some arborio rice to creamy perfection and then stirred in a mix of steamed asparagus, cooked wild mushrooms, a few spices and parmesan cheese to thicken things up a tad more. To make it a full meal, I added slices of spicy rubbed chicken tenderloins.

I put together one of my favorite ‘quick’ meals tonight, EatingWell’s Southwestern Tofu Scramble. It’s a filling dish of crumbled firm tofu, corn, zucchini, scallions and monterey jack cheese mixed in a spicy blend of freshly ground cumin, hot chili powder and cayenne pepper. A ‘lil dabble of salsa goes on the top and it’s finished off with a pinch of finely chopped cilantro.

I put together EatingWell’s Parmesan Spinach Cakes tonight and was extremely pleased with the result. I varied from recipe by using frozen spinach instead of the fresh stuff, almost doubled the parmesan, added a little mustard powder, cayenne pepper and some freshly grated nutmeg. I tossed a ‘lil salmon salad on the side and shoveled it all down. Delicious!

Looking for a new source of recipes, I gave Clean Eating’s Fish and Chips a shot tonight. I toasted some 12 grain bread from Whole Foods and then gave it a spin in the food processor to make some homemade breadcrumbs. I then used them to bread some cod fillets that I promptly tossed in the oven. I added a bit of dill weed, hot chili powder and cayenne to the breading to add some flavor (and was very happy I did.) On the side of the fish were some paper thin roasted sweet potato slices created from my mandolin. The recipe took some serious tweaking to achieve delicious, but in the end it made it there.
